response.answer_text: The Great Depression happened. As a result, not only did FDR order the mint to stop making $20 gold coins, but anyone owning more than $100 in gold coins or bullion were supposed to turn in the excess amount to the Treasury and get paid paper money for it. People being people, a lot of $20 gold coins were hidden away and survive. You can buy a common date, circulated $20 gold coin today for a relatively small surcharge over its gold value.

You’re talking about the $20.00 double Eagle gold coin. They stopped minting them in 1933. Many minted before that time got returned to the mint and were melted do3n and made into gold bars. Much of that is stored at Fort Knox Kentucky.
